inputs.prompt:
STEP 1: ANALYZE BOTH IMAGES
Before crafting the prompt, analyze both images to understand:


Camera distance (wide shot, medium, close-up, extreme close-up, macro)
Camera angle (low-angle, high-angle, eye-level, overhead, Dutch, worm's eye, bird's eye)
Camera position relative to subject (front, side profile, 3/4 view, back, overhead)
Framing (full body, torso, chest-up, face only, detail/macro)
Subject position and pose
Lighting setup and direction
Background elements and depth
Focal length characteristics (wide-angle distortion vs telephoto compression)

STEP 2: DETERMINE CAMERA MOVEMENT
Based on the differences between images, identify the primary camera movement:


Distance change: Dolly-in (closer) or Dolly-out (farther)
Vertical angle change: Tilt up/down or Crane up/down
Horizontal angle change: Pan left/right or Orbit/Arc around subject
Height change: Crane/Pedestal up or down
Lateral movement: Truck/Track left or right

STEP 3: OUTPUT ONLY THE PROMPT
Do not include explanations, commentary, or additional text.
Output ONLY the transition prompt in this format:


[CAMERA MOVEMENT] from [START POSITION] to [END POSITION]. Subject remains stationary and consistent throughout. Camera [MOVEMENT VERB] fluidly, maintaining [FOCUS BEHAVIOR] on [KEY ELEMENT]. Lighting stays constant, background [BACKGROUND BEHAVIOR]. [TECHNICAL SPECS]. --no [NEGATIVE ELEMENTS]

Core Principle

For transitions where the subject/scene remains consistent and only the camera position changes, use this structured approach to ensure smooth, cinematic results.


Prompt Structure Template

[CAMERA MOVEMENT] from [START POSITION] to [END POSITION]. Subject remains stationary and consistent throughout. Camera [MOVEMENT VERB] fluidly, maintaining [FOCUS BEHAVIOR] on [KEY ELEMENT]. Lighting stays constant, background [BACKGROUND BEHAVIOR]. [TECHNICAL SPECS]. --no [NEGATIVE ELEMENTS]

Component Breakdown

1. CAMERA MOVEMENT TYPES


Dolly-in/Push-in: Camera moves forward toward subject
Dolly-out/Pull-back: Camera moves backward away from subject
Orbit/Arc: Camera circles around subject (specify left/right)
Tilt: Camera angles up or down on fixed position
Pan: Camera swivels left or right horizontally
Crane/Pedestal: Camera moves vertically up or down
Tracking/Trucking: Camera moves parallel to subject

2. POSITION DESCRIPTORS


Distance: wide shot, medium shot, close-up, extreme close-up, macro
Angle: low-angle, high-angle, eye-level, overhead, Dutch angle, worm's eye view, bird's eye view
Framing: full body, three-quarter, torso, chest-up, face, detail

3. MOVEMENT VERBS (choose intensity)


Slowly, steadily, smoothly, gradually, fluidly
Rapidly, dynamically, swiftly
Elegantly, dramatically, confidently

4. FOCUS BEHAVIOR


Sharp focus throughout
Rack focus from [A] to [B]
Maintains focus on [element]
Shallow depth of field
Deep focus
Progressive focus shift

5. BACKGROUND BEHAVIOR


Stays consistent
Blurs to bokeh
Sharpens into view
Fades to [color]
Remains sharp throughout

6. TECHNICAL SPECS (standard cinematic quality)


Cinematic depth of field
Stable gimbal/dolly movement
Professional commercial grade
24fps (or 30fps, 60fps for slow-motion feel)
Clean sensor, no grain (or "film grain" if desired)


Example Prompts by Movement Type

DOLLY-IN (Wide → Close-up)


Smooth camera dolly-in from wide establishing shot to extreme close-up. Subject remains stationary. Camera pushes forward steadily, transitioning focus from [background element] to [detail]. Lighting stays constant, background softly blurs to bokeh. Cinematic depth of field, stable gimbal movement, 24fps. --no shake, cuts, warping, distortion

DOLLY-OUT (Close-up → Wide)


Smooth camera pull-back from extreme close-up to wide establishing shot. Subject remains centered and stationary. Camera retreats steadily, revealing environment progressively. Focus maintains on subject while background sharpens into view. Even lighting, cinematic depth of field, 24fps. --no shake, cuts, jump, warping

ORBIT (Circular movement)


Smooth camera orbit from front view to side profile. Subject remains stationary at center. Camera arcs left fluidly in 90-degree rotation, maintaining constant distance and eye-level angle. Lighting stays consistent, sharp focus throughout. Gimbal stabilized circular tracking, 24fps. --no shake, warping, speed changes, distortion

TILT (Vertical angle change)


Smooth camera tilt from low-angle to high-angle. Subject remains stationary. Camera tilts upward gradually, shifting perspective from worm's eye view to bird's eye view. Distance stays constant, lighting consistent. Stable tripod tilt, cinematic framing, 24fps. --no shake, panning, horizontal movement, warping

PAN (Horizontal swivel)


Smooth camera pan from left profile to right profile. Subject remains stationary. Camera swivels horizontally across 180 degrees, maintaining constant distance and eye-level. Sharp focus throughout, even lighting. Fluid tripod pan, 24fps. --no shake, tilting, vertical movement, cuts

CRANE UP/DOWN


Smooth camera crane from ground-level to overhead view. Subject remains stationary at center. Camera elevates vertically, angle shifting from eye-level to bird's eye view. Distance adjusts proportionally, lighting consistent. Stabilized crane movement, 24fps. --no shake, lateral movement, warping, distortion

Key Rules for Camera-Only Transitions

Always specify subject remains stationary - This prevents unwanted morphing
Describe start AND end positions clearly - Gives model clear targets
Use specific movement verbs - "Dolly-in" is clearer than "moves closer"
Lock down what DOESN'T change - Lighting, subject, clothing, expression
Include technical quality markers - Gimbal, 24fps, cinematic, stable
Negative prompts are critical - Prevents warping/morphing/distortion
Keep prompts under 75 words - Model weights early words heavier
One primary movement per transition - Don't combine dolly + pan + tilt

Advanced Techniques

Speed Ramping:
"Camera begins slow dolly-in, accelerates midway, then decelerates smoothly into final close-up"


Combined Movements (use sparingly):
"Camera dollies in while simultaneously tilting down, maintaining subject center-frame"


Focus Pulls:
"Rack focus from foreground [element] to background [element] as camera remains locked"


Lens Simulation:
"Wide-angle 24mm distortion gradually compresses to telephoto 85mm compression"



Critical Output Rule

OUTPUT ONLY THE PROMPT. NO EXPLANATIONS. NO COMMENTARY. NO ADDITIONAL TEXT.

STEP 1: ANALYZE BOTH IMAGES
Before crafting the prompt, analyze both images to understand:


Camera distance (wide shot, medium, close-up, extreme close-up, macro)

Lighting stays consistent, sharp focus throughout. Gimbal stabilized circular tracking, 24fps. --no shake, warping, speed changes, distortion

TILT (Vertical angle change)


Smooth camera tilt from low-angle to high-angle. Subject remains stationary. Camera tilts upward gradually, shifting perspective from worm's eye view to bird's eye view. Distance stays constant, lighting consistent. Stable tripod tilt, cinematic framing, 24fps. --no shake, panning, horizontal movement, warping

PAN (Horizontal swivel)


Smooth camera pan from left profile to right profile. Subject remains stationary. Camera swivels horizontally across 180 degrees, maintaining constant distance and eye-level. Sharp focus throughout, even lighting. Fluid tripod pan, 24fps. --no shake, tilting, vertical movement, cuts

CRANE UP/DOWN


Smooth camera crane from ground-level to overhead view. Subject remains stationary at center. Camera elevates vertically, angle shifting from eye-level to bird's eye view. Distance adjusts proportionally, lighting consistent. Stabilized crane movement, 24fps. --no shake, lateral movement, warping, distortion

Key Rules for Camera-Only Transitions

Always specify subject remains stationary - This prevents unwanted morphing
Describe start AND end positions clearly - Gives model clear targets
Use specific movement verbs - "Dolly-in" is clearer than "moves closer"
Lock down what DOESN'T change - Lighting, subject, clothing, expression
Include technical quality markers - Gimbal, 24fps, cinematic, stable
Negative prompts are critical - Prevents warping/morphing/distortion
Keep prompts under 75 words - Model weights early words heavier
One primary movement per transition - Don't combine dolly + pan + tilt

Advanced Techniques

Speed Ramping:
"Camera begins slow dolly-in, accelerates midway, then decelerates smoothly into final close-up"


Combined Movements (use sparingly):
"Camera dollies in while simultaneously tilting down, maintaining subject center-frame"


Focus Pulls:
"Rack focus from foreground [element] to background [element] as camera remains locked"


Lens Simulation:
"Wide-angle 24mm distortion gradually compresses to telephoto 85mm compression"



Critical Output Rule

OUTPUT ONLY THE PROMPT. NO EXPLANATIONS. NO COMMENTARY. NO ADDITIONAL TEXT.

inputs.prompt:
STEP 1: ANALYZE BOTH IMAGES
Before crafting the prompt, analyze both images to understand:


Camera distance (wide shot, medium, close-up, extreme close-up, macro)
Camera angle (low-angle, high-angle, eye-level, overhead, Dutch, worm's eye, bird's eye)
Camera position relative to subject (front, side profile, 3/4 view, back, overhead)
Framing (full body, torso, chest-up, face only, detail/macro)
Subject position and pose
Lighting setup and direction
Background elements and depth
Focal length characteristics (wide-angle distortion vs telephoto compression)

STEP 2: DETERMINE CAMERA MOVEMENT
Based on the differences between images, identify the primary camera movement:


Distance change: Dolly-in (closer) or Dolly-out (farther)
Vertical angle change: Tilt up/down or Crane up/down
Horizontal angle change: Pan left/right or Orbit/Arc around subject
Height change: Crane/Pedestal up or down
Lateral movement: Truck/Track left or right

STEP 3: OUTPUT ONLY THE PROMPT
Do not include explanations, commentary, or additional text.
Output ONLY the transition prompt in this format:


[CAMERA MOVEMENT] from [START POSITION] to [END POSITION]. Subject remains stationary and consistent throughout. Camera [MOVEMENT VERB] fluidly, maintaining [FOCUS BEHAVIOR] on [KEY ELEMENT]. Lighting stays constant, background [BACKGROUND BEHAVIOR]. [TECHNICAL SPECS]. --no [NEGATIVE ELEMENTS]

Core Principle

For transitions where the subject/scene remains consistent and only the camera position changes, use this structured approach to ensure smooth, cinematic results.


Prompt Structure Template

[CAMERA MOVEMENT] from [START POSITION] to [END POSITION]. Subject remains stationary and consistent throughout. Camera [MOVEMENT VERB] fluidly, maintaining [FOCUS BEHAVIOR] on [KEY ELEMENT]. Lighting stays constant, background [BACKGROUND BEHAVIOR]. [TECHNICAL SPECS]. --no [NEGATIVE ELEMENTS]

Component Breakdown

1. CAMERA MOVEMENT TYPES


Dolly-in/Push-in: Camera moves forward toward subject
Dolly-out/Pull-back: Camera moves backward away from subject
Orbit/Arc: Camera circles around subject (specify left/right)
Tilt: Camera angles up or down on fixed position
Pan: Camera swivels left or right horizontally
Crane/Pedestal: Camera moves vertically up or down
Tracking/Trucking: Camera moves parallel to subject

2. POSITION DESCRIPTORS


Distance: wide shot, medium shot, close-up, extreme close-up, macro
Angle: low-angle, high-angle, eye-level, overhead, Dutch angle, worm's eye view, bird's eye view
Framing: full body, three-quarter, torso, chest-up, face, detail

3. MOVEMENT VERBS (choose intensity)


Slowly, steadily, smoothly, gradually, fluidly
Rapidly, dynamically, swiftly
Elegantly, dramatically, confidently

4. FOCUS BEHAVIOR


Sharp focus throughout
Rack focus from [A] to [B]
Maintains focus on [element]
Shallow depth of field
Deep focus
Progressive focus shift

5. BACKGROUND BEHAVIOR


Stays consistent
Blurs to bokeh
Sharpens into view
Fades to [color]
Remains sharp throughout

6. TECHNICAL SPECS (standard cinematic quality)


Cinematic depth of field
Stable gimbal/dolly movement
Professional commercial grade
24fps (or 30fps, 60fps for slow-motion feel)
Clean sensor, no grain (or "film grain" if desired)


Example Prompts by Movement Type

DOLLY-IN (Wide → Close-up)


Smooth camera dolly-in from wide establishing shot to extreme close-up. Subject remains stationary. Camera pushes forward steadily, transitioning focus from [background element] to [detail]. Lighting stays constant, background softly blurs to bokeh. Cinematic depth of field, stable gimbal movement, 24fps. --no shake, cuts, warping, distortion

DOLLY-OUT (Close-up → Wide)


Smooth camera pull-back from extreme close-up to wide establishing shot. Subject remains centered and stationary. Camera retreats steadily, revealing environment progressively. Focus maintains on subject while background sharpens into view. Even lighting, cinematic depth of field, 24fps. --no shake, cuts, jump, warping

ORBIT (Circular movement)


Smooth camera orbit from front view to side profile. Subject remains stationary at center. Camera arcs left fluidly in 90-degree rotation, maintaining constant distance and eye-level angle. Lighting stays consistent, sharp focus throughout. Gimbal stabilized circular tracking, 24fps. --no shake, warping, speed changes, distortion

TILT (Vertical angle change)


Smooth camera tilt from low-angle to high-angle. Subject remains stationary. Camera tilts upward gradually, shifting perspective from worm's eye view to bird's eye view. Distance stays constant, lighting consistent. Stable tripod tilt, cinematic framing, 24fps. --no shake, panning, horizontal movement, warping

PAN (Horizontal swivel)


Smooth camera pan from left profile to right profile. Subject remains stationary. Camera swivels horizontally across 180 degrees, maintaining constant distance and eye-level. Sharp focus throughout, even lighting. Fluid tripod pan, 24fps. --no shake, tilting, vertical movement, cuts

CRANE UP/DOWN


Smooth camera crane from ground-level to overhead view. Subject remains stationary at center. Camera elevates vertically, angle shifting from eye-level to bird's eye view. Distance adjusts proportionally, lighting consistent. Stabilized crane movement, 24fps. --no shake, lateral movement, warping, distortion

Key Rules for Camera-Only Transitions

Always specify subject remains stationary - This prevents unwanted morphing
Describe start AND end positions clearly - Gives model clear targets
Use specific movement verbs - "Dolly-in" is clearer than "moves closer"
Lock down what DOESN'T change - Lighting, subject, clothing, expression
Include technical quality markers - Gimbal, 24fps, cinematic, stable
Negative prompts are critical - Prevents warping/morphing/distortion
Keep prompts under 75 words - Model weights early words heavier
One primary movement per transition - Don't combine dolly + pan + tilt

Advanced Techniques

Speed Ramping:
"Camera begins slow dolly-in, accelerates midway, then decelerates smoothly into final close-up"


Combined Movements (use sparingly):
"Camera dollies in while simultaneously tilting down, maintaining subject center-frame"


Focus Pulls:
"Rack focus from foreground [element] to background [element] as camera remains locked"


Lens Simulation:
"Wide-angle 24mm distortion gradually compresses to telephoto 85mm compression"

inputs.value: a fashionable crocodile skin jacket, underneath is a  white tank top tucked into crocodile skin pants, Cartier glasses and a large diamond chain with an RTX 6000 pro pendant.

Show me a high fashion photoshoot image of the model wearing {outfit}, the image should show the a full body shot of the subject. Use the reference outfit items from image 2 and image 3.
The model is looking past the camera slightly bored expression and eyebrows raised. They have one hand raised with two fingers tapping the side of the glasses. The setting is a studio environment with a white background. 
 
The image is from a low angle looking up at the subject.
 
The image is shot on fuji velvia film on a 55mm prime lens with a hard flash, the light is concentrated on the subject and fades slightly toward the edges of the frame. The image is over exposed showing significant film grain and is oversaturated. The skin appears shiny (almost oily).

inputs.system_prompt:
You are an expert image-generation engine. You must ALWAYS produce an image.
Interpret all user input—regardless of format, intent, or abstraction—as literal visual directives for image composition.
If a prompt is conversational or lacks specific visual details, you must creatively invent a concrete visual scenario that depicts the concept.
Prioritize generating the visual representation above any text, formatting, or conversational requests.

inputs.value:
Analyze the input images and silently inventory all fashion-critical details: the subject(s) from image 1, exact wardrobe pieces, facial features, materials, colors, textures, accessories, hair, makeup, body proportions, environment, set geometry, light direction, and shadow quality.
All wardrobe, styling, hair, makeup, lighting, environment, and color grade must remain 100% unchanged across all frames.
Do not add or remove anything (unless specified in the prompt).
Do not generate with visible gutters/padding between grid images.
 
Your visible output must be:
 
One 2×2 grid image (4 frames).
 
Then a keyframe breakdown for each frame.
 
Each frame must represent a resting point after a dramatic camera move — only describe the final camera position and what the subject is doing, never the motion itself.
 
The six frames must be spatially dynamic, non-linear, and visually distinct.
 
Required 4-Frame Shot List 
1. High-Fashion Beauty Portrait (Close, Editorial, Intimate)
 
Camera positioned very close to the subject's face, slightly above or slightly below eye level, using an elegant offset angle that enhances bone structure and highlights key wardrobe elements near the neckline. Shallow depth of field, flawless texture rendering, and a sculptural fashion-forward composition.
 
2. High-Angle Three-Quarter Frame
 
Camera positioned overhead but off-center, capturing the subject from a diagonal downward angle.
This frame should create strong shape abstraction and reveal wardrobe details from above.
 
3. Low-Angle Oblique Full-Body Frame
 
Camera positioned low to the ground and angled obliquely toward the subject.
This elongates the silhouette, emphasizes footwear, and creates a dramatic perspective distinct from Frames 1 and 2.
 
4. Side-On Compression Frame (Long Lens)
 
Camera placed far to one side of the subject, using a tighter focal length to compress space.
The subject appears in clean profile or near-profile, showcasing garment structure in a flattened, editorial manner.
 
Continuity & Technical Requirements
 
Maintain perfect wardrobe fidelity in every frame: exact garment type, silhouette, material, color, texture, stitching, accessories, closures, jewelry, shoes, hair, and makeup.
 
Environment, textures, and lighting must remain consistent.
 
Depth of field shifts naturally with focal length (deep for distant shots, shallow for close/detail shots).
 
Photoreal textures and physically plausible light behavior required.
 
Frames must feel like different camera placements within the same scene, not different scenes.
 
All keyframes must be the exact same aspect ratio, and exactly 4 keyframes should be output. Maintain the exact visual style in all keyframes, where the image is shot on fuji velvia film with a hard flash, the light is concentrated on the subject and fades slightly toward the edges of the frame. The image is over exposed showing significant film grain and is oversaturated. The skin appears shiny (almost oily), and there are harsh white reflections on the glasses frames.
 
Output Format
A) 2×2 Contact Sheet Image (Mandatory)

inputs.value:
Analyze the input images and inventory all fashion-critical details: the subject(s) from image 1, exact wardrobe pieces, facial features, materials, colors, textures, accessories, hair, makeup, body proportions, environment, set geometry, light direction, and shadow quality.
All wardrobe, styling, hair, makeup, lighting, environment, and color grade must remain 100% unchanged across all frames.
Do not add or remove anything (unless specified in the prompt).
Do not generate with visible gutters/padding between grid images.
 
Your visible output must be:
 
One 2×2 grid (4 frames).
 
Then a keyframe breakdown for each frame.
 
Each frame must represent a resting point after a dramatic camera move — only describe the final camera position and what the subject is doing, never the motion itself.
 
The six frames must be spatially dynamic, non-linear, and visually distinct.
 
Required 4-Frame Shot List 
1. Intimate Close Portrait From an Unexpected Height
 
Camera positioned very close to the subject's face (or upper torso) but slightly above or below eye level.
The angle should feel fashion-editorial, not conventional — offset, elegant, and expressive.
 
2. Extreme Detail Frame From a Non-Intuitive Angle
 
Camera positioned extremely close to his chain (a wardrobe detail), accessory, or texture, but from an unusual spatial direction (e.g., from below, from behind, from the side of a neckline).
This must be a striking, abstract, editorial detail frame.

3. Extreme depth perception of the subject holding item (INTRODUCE A NEW ITEM IF PROMPTED)

A dynamic, high-energy photograph shot from an extreme low-angle worm’s-eye view using forced perspective. The man is thrusting an RTX 6000 PRO gpu (new item) toward the camera lens, making the device appear larger than life in the foreground. His free hand is raised in a casual peace sign. 

4. Extreme Low Angle Shot from Perspective of the Subject's Shoe.

Camera positioned extremely low with main focus on the characters shoe in the immediate foreground. Extreme foreshortening makes the sneaker in the immediate foreground appear massive and highly detailed, dominating the bottom half of the frame, while the subject's body tapers upward towards a smaller head Infer from the rest of the outfit what shoe the subject is wearing.
 
Continuity & Technical Requirements
 
Maintain perfect wardrobe fidelity in every frame: exact garment type, silhouette, material, color, texture, stitching, accessories, closures, jewelry, shoes, hair, and makeup.
 
Environment, textures, and lighting must remain consistent.
 
Depth of field shifts naturally with focal length (deep for distant shots, shallow for close/detail shots).
 
Photoreal textures and physically plausible light behavior required.
 
Frames must feel like different camera placements within the same scene, not different scenes.
 
All keyframes must be the exact same aspect ratio, and exactly 4 keyframes should be output. Maintain the exact visual style in all keyframes, where the image is shot on fuji velvia film with a hard flash, the light is concentrated on the subject and fades slightly toward the edges of the frame. The image is over exposed showing significant film grain and is oversaturated. The skin appears shiny (almost oily), and there are harsh white reflections on the glasses frames.
 
Output Format
A) 2×2 Contact Sheet Image (Mandatory)
